summary: When a reporter is assigned to decipher newspaper magnate Charles Foster Kane's (Orson Welles) dying words, his investigation gradually reveals the fascinating portrait of a complex man who rose from obscurity to staggering heights. Though Kane's friend and colleague Jedediah Leland (Joseph Cotten), and his mistress, Susan Alexander (Dorothy Comingore), shed fragments of light on Kane's life, the reporter fears he may never penetrate the mystery of the elusive man's final word, "Rosebud."

reviews.content: A wonderful plot pillared by an intriguing storyline with novel cinematography and talented cast has earned its high merit among film connoisseurs. Simply brilliant and one of the most treasured classics of all time.

Need one say more than "greatest film of all time"? Orson Welles deliberately obliterated the accepted style of filmmaking in Hollywood at the time, and in doing so created one of the first great masterpieces with sound. Welles' own sprawling performance is the centerpiece of the film. Without Welles as the titularly immortalized character, the film would work merely as substance without the depth of his performance. It is also safe to say that Citizen Kane is one of the best debut films of all time, if not certainly the best. There is no higher praise that this film can receive that it has not already been given, and for excellent reasons.

As by many seen the best movie of all time, Citizen Kane didnt fully blow me away. There is of course no denying that Citizen Kane is in fact one of, if not the most influential movie in the history of film. The way that Citizen Kane explores new ways of filmmaking, was insane for that period of time. Citizen Kane has some gorgeous camerawork, framing, production design and cinematography. The performances are certainly great, especially of Orson Welles himself. The story itself was solid, I definitely found that 3rd act was heads above the rest, especially that ending, the rest was solid work. Maybe I had to high of an expectation for this movie, then I should have, however there is no denying the impact this movie has had on cinema of the years in the past and on the years to come, great movie!

SHREK 2 is better than shrek 1 heres whyGreat sequels are hard to pull off. They're especially hard when the first film was a colossal hit. And that's exactly what Shrek was. Looking back on the film that introduced everyone's favorite green ogre to the world, it's easy to lose sight of just how big of a sensation it was. Besides being a critical and commercial smash hit, the film played in the competition for the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival and went on to win the first-ever Best Animated Feature Oscar at the Academy Awards. Shrek 2 had a long road ahead of it if it wanted to match this success, let alone top it.

As the Disney renaissance dwindled after a historic run of animated films in the 90s, Shrek's irreverent brand of humor and pop-culture references perfectly captured cultural fatigue with the Disney princess films. After a decade of Disney films where heroines scoured the ends of the Earth in search of true love, Shrek gained its power by being the antithesis of all that.

Gotta give the young Mr. Wells his props for both direction and acting;  he even ages convincingly through the film.   Yeah, technically it's All That and a Bag of Chips, though it can't be called "entertaining."   Its contemporary audiences doubtless knew that Wells was skewering William Randolph Hearst, though he had to hide the true meaning of "Rosebud" behind a plot device.  The movie is, however, notably better than Well's second effort, the utter snoozefest known as "The Magnificent Ambersons" which wasn't even good, let alone magnificent.

Simply put, this is a film of so many layers you could probably watch it every day for a month and still find more to ponder. In concept it's simple, a film about the life of a  man. It ends with a humbling reminder that really, we're not so different from each other after all.

That is not to say I didn't love it, this film is absolutely brilliant in every respect. I just more admire it rather than adore it, but I completely understand its reputation as a classic. The cinematography is enough to earn the film's reputation, every shot, every angle is exemplary and has so much visual drama, and you never know from looking at Citizen Kane that it was made on a shoestring budget. That is not all though. Bernard Hermann's score is superb, the story while not easy to understand at first is interesting and the screenplay is thought-provoking. Not only does Orson Welles direct impeccably, he turns in a magnificent performance as Charles Foster Kane, while the supporting acting is excellent too. People may dismiss Citizen Kane as boring and dull, and I have known people outside of IMDb to say that, but I have yet to hear any of those people to say it is not well-made or directed. As for me, I loved this film very much, and while my praise doesn't completely go beyond sheer admiration I cannot deny it is a great film. 10/10 Bethany Cox
hands down, the greatest movie of all time

Left me feeling cold, I must say. The cinematography is obviously way ahead of its time. I loved the way it was lit, the use of chiaroscuro- with so many of its characters drawn in silhouette and shadow gives the film the perfect visual aid for its narratives mystery. Also ahead of its time was the non linear narrative arch- and in particular Kane's 'breakfast scenes' with his first wife were really great. But I just didn't engage with or like any of the characters and as such didn't care at all what happened to them. The meaning of 'rosebud' wasn't one I was interested in, as I didn't care about Kane. Kane's descent from young idealist to self-interested megalomaniac certainly draws a lot of interesting parallels with today's billionaires controlling our news, and Welles performance is tour de force, but the whole film was delivered like a news story in a tabloid and didn't have enough heart or soul for me.

Citizen Kane is a feat in filmmaking and storytelling. I will tell you, you're going to have to see multiple times to fully appreciate this film. I always asked myself why this film is considered the greatest of all time, but it was answered, while watching the film, by seeing feats of cinematography, acting, and important characters. An All Time Classic. The cinematography, editing, special effects, pacing and plot are all phenomenally well done. I was shocked how modern this felt. The acting is very well done though it isn't phenomenal as it has that theater style acting that works well but is slightly dated but never really detracts from anything. The soundtrack is very well done also but I would say its a slight tick below everything else. It never feels like it makes a scene or is memorable but does a great job consistently enhancing the mood of a scene when needed. My advice would be don't be intimidated watching this. Just go in with no expectations and you'll see this for what it is fundamentally. Although this isn't one of my favorites this is an All Time Fictional Bio Drama Classic and an All Time Classic For Sure.

An undistributed masterpiece that Orson Welles cemented his genius in film with his debut of "Citizen Kane".  "Citizen Kane" is the story of one man, but is portrayed so genuine that it truly represents humanity as a whole. A gripping and captivating film that stays with you, in your thoughts and dreams. Everyone, whether a film lover in touch with many classics, or someone who wants to see film in a way that revolutionized the film industry, should watch Citizen Kane.  To this day, it has a huge impact on the world of cinema and the auteur.  Just like the audience watching the smoke ascending to the night sky, it has a profound and everlasting impact.

Walles has established himself as a "master genius", intellectually crafting a story, history and biography that has transcend fiction. The characters appear larger then life with emotional aspects constructed by a verbal and cinematographical style. Thus making the characters and plot bound, making a memory appear larger then it actually is, and Kane a memory that fades like time.

Orson Welles leggendario.
Il primo film del giovanissimo Welles (e anche primo capolavoro) distrugge e deforma tutto il concetto di cinema instaurato fino a quel momento. Quarto Potere, nonostante sia stato, per ovvi motivi politici, stroncato dalla critica, portando addirittura l'RKO al fallimento, è uno dei primi 5 film più importanti della storia del cinema. 
Forse mai era stata data carta bianca ad un così giovane regista, che sull'onda della passione teatrale Shakespeariana, costruisce ed interpreta un personaggio che il cinema ha riproposto nel tempo innumerevoli volte.
Tecnicamente perfetto, con l'utilizzo innovativo e spiazzante del Grandangolo e di una fotografia pulita e profonda.
Welles dimostra che il cinema può essere cambiato e può mutare con la tecnica e con nuovi concetti di strutturazione e predisposizione dell'immagine.
Opera d'arte assoluta.

While technically impressive for the time and the acting is extremely good considering most of it's actors were not screen actors, the movie doesn't exactly hold up in a modern sense. The pacing simply to slow that a two hour long movie, it simply struggled to keep me entertained.

"Citizen Kane" (1941) es lo que considero el equivalente cinematográfico a ese bello retrato que hace un pintor de una figura histórica. Aprovechando al máximo sus 2 horas de duración y honrando su título como la mejor película en la historia del cine, esta obra maestra en iluminación y perspectiva no cae en mostrar solo dramas románticos y arrebatos sin sentido, si no que nos lleva en un viaje a través de los capítulos fenomenales y ocasionalmente intensos de la vida de un ser importante y poderoso, narrados excelentemente desde varias perspectivas. Por cada segmento al menos un aplauso, es imposible no querer analizar, ya que a medida que la película progresa se le permite al espectador sentir intriga e interés por la vida del legendario Charles Foster Kane, preparándolo para el gran giro final. Esplendorosa, impredecible y magistralmente citable, Orson Welles elevo el estándar en muchos aspectos del cine como lo conocemos dirigiendo, produciendo, escribiendo y protagonizando la todavía joya cinematográfica estelar conocida como "Citizen Kane" (1941).
Best film of all time!

Wow, really nice use of eerie and atmospheric imagery. That palace/castle that Kane lived in has beautiful architecture. His estate, which he named Xanadu, was massive and insanely expensive. He had his own zoo, collection of old relics including paintings and statues, and his whole castle/palace was built out of pure marble on top of a winding mountain. Very lively and electric the way they're presenting the story and all the information about Kane. Respect towards Charles Kane, he's one of the wealthiest people in the world and still wants to run a newspaper inquirer in order to inform the public of the truth. Omg, Rosebud was the name of the sled he had as a child! The last thing he had as a child before he got moved out to New York and left his mother and father. The whole time he just wanted to go back in time and be a kid again. That last scene with the sled burning was probably the most powerful one in the whole movie. It answers everything and brings everything full circle. It's brilliant really. 

Meticulously and masterfully filmed with a keen attention to detail. This movie is filled with creative ideas in terms of technicality and cinematography. It's innovative for it's time and definitely ahead of it as well. The atmospheric lighting, the way the camera moves, the way the story is presented - it's all brilliant. The set designs are impressive and grand. 20 minutes in and I can already see why this movie is regarded as one of the best. With all that being said though, it isn't the most entertaining, fun or thrilling story. It's actually kind of gloomy and miserable. One in which we see the demise of someone who could've made a difference but squandered it instead with foolish decisions because of their pride, ego and selfishness. Kane's life became an empty one, a meaningless one towards the end. Where he filled his void with buying material things like statues and art. Quite somber and dreary really. 

All Kane wanted was to be happy. He longed to go back to being a child again, when he lived with his mother and father simply playing in the snow. To actually have a childhood and a normal upbringing. The reason none of Kane's closest friends knew what rosebud meant was because he never opened up to them about it. He never opened up to anyone. No one ever really knew the real Charles Foster Kane. He was a very closed off person. A very sensitive and hurt person who hid the pain well. It's quite a dreary and sobering movie but one that also has a very meaningful and important message. I can see why it's regarded as one of the greatest movies of all time, but honestly, this isn't a movie that I would be itching to watch again for fun. This is more of a movie you watch to learn from whether it's with the story or the innovative movie techniques used throughout like the editing, cinematography, and special effects. Overall, I thought it was a masterfully crafted movie with a meaningful message, it left an impression on me. I'd like to watch it again sometime.

The entire movie tells a story of the life of a wealthy businessman by the name of Kane as people try to find out what his baffling last word before his death, "rose bud" means. While this movie challenges the capitalist ideals, it simultaneously dives into the core human desires that we often fail to realize. Its astonishing revelation at the end of the movie is one of the most indelible moments in the cinematic history.

Another classic that won't seem all that impressive by today's standards, but if you watch some of the other movies from the year of its release that were considered Oscar contenders first and then watch this one, it'll blow you away.  Just worlds beyond what was being done at the time.  Won't necessarily dominate by today's standards, but that's because today's standards are the result of a lifetime of imitating and improving the things Citizen Kane brought to the table.
Maybe not the BEST film of all time, but it's still fascinating.

This is not a bad movie yet I don't think it's a great one. I'll get the positives out of the way, I liked the symbolism of the Rosebud at the end and what it was meant to represent to the main character, along with how the film was made and the originally executed transitions that took place between scenes/time periods. I also liked what they chose to do with his relationships and the deeper meanings that the film chose to explore about love and what it means for the person giving it and receiving it.

However, the main story is not really interesting and did not fascinate me at all. The newspaper business is hardly something I'm interested in and the main character was only relatable in just a few scenes. Many people say this is objectively the best film ever made, and I think that's unfair since there's now 80 years worth of films that have come out since then. What's the point of having a favorite or appreciating something new if it can't concretely ever measure up to something from the past?? Film is something that's meant to adapt to the time period in which its production takes place, and while this movie might've greatly dazzled many in the past, I think there's a lot of merit to appreciate other things even more that came after it. It's important to appreciate what it did for film but I refuse to get hung up on its significance and dismiss most other subsequent amazing films like some have been guilty of doing.

Very thick plot to comprehend, as the film dives into the beauty and horror of wealth and fame. On one hand, you have a rich politician with unlimited wealth and "friends." On the other, you have a lonely and depressed man who misses his family and is searching for real happiness, unfabricated love, and joy. The film dives into the true meaning of success and power, and whether or not money and power can truly buy happiness. The famous "Rosebud" sentence is one that leaves the whole film a mystery until the end while illustrating a man's life explicitly. Truly an iconic film that is a must-see.

The disordered storytelling and amazing editing make for one of the greatest pieces of cinema ever. The movie deserves all the praise it gets.

For a film critic or lover to call Citizen Kane anything less than perfect, is to damage their own creditability. And yet, here we are.
Am I saying this film is bad? HELL NO! The acting is fantastic, the characters are likable, the dialogue is witty, the editing is masterful, the use of lighting is stunning, and the cinematography is gorgeous.
Nearly everything about this film is perfect...all except for one thing. At the very beginning, we are introduced to the life of our main character, via documentary within the film. Not only do I feel this was unnecessary as the film itself is meant to show us the life of Kane, but it also goes on for WAY too long.
Even though saying that may damage my reputation, It's still an absolute marvel of film making that can still be marveled at even nearly a century later.

Here's the thing.  I watch a LOT of movies.  Some I consider 'good' or better, some OK I guess, and many many that are 'bad'.  My opinions on many movies differ from the average joe.  For instsance, 'Lincoln' and 'The Lighthouse' have astonishingly great ratings on Rotten Tomatoes.  I hated them both.  'The Lighthouse'  was a trainwreck of weird, disturbing, boring cinema.  'Lincoln' was like trying hard to listen to that guy who lost you  minutes ago and never shuts up!  The guy babbles on and on and for the 40 minutes I coiuld stand of it, is as boring as one could imagine. Nothing happens!  This brings me to Citizen Kane.  Forgive me for not having enough patience with it maybe, but I tried watching it twice, and both times I had to turn it off within the first 20 minutes.  I know movies sometimes take a while to get going.  I like some classic movies ('It's a Wonderful life', '12 Angry Men', and 'How Green Was My Valley' are among my favorites).  But this entire storyline is about as boring as a movie can get.  Is it about newspaper guy? Politics?  I don't know. What I do know is I've seen over 700 non-animated movies in my lifetime, and I'd say half or more are not very good.  But they all kept my interest enough to keep watching. 'Citizen Kane' had me scrambling for the remote twice!  Even the plot is uninteresting. I just don't get it.

People may dismiss Citizen Kane as boring and dull, and I have known people outside of IMDb to say that, but I have yet to hear any of those people to say it is not well-made or directed. It seems pointless to outline the virtues of a film that has been written about as extensively as Citizen Kane.  Arguably the greatest movie ever made (it is), arguably the most influential film ever made (it is), arguably the most technically innovative film ever made (it is), true fans of cinema need to read about it, study it, watch it and then rewatch it to fully appreciate all of the wonders that it has to offer and to marvel at its perfection.

Orson Welles' masterpiece Citizen Kane is considered, according to the American Film Institution, the greatest movie ever made, and for very good reason. This movie is about the life of Charles Foster Kane, and the meaning of his last words: "Rosebud". Citizen Kane is so important because of the technical accomplishments made which were incredibly revolutionary and ahead of their time. The use of lighting is incredible, using dark and heavy shadows during sadder moments, and the opposite for more jovial moments. The use of lighting is extremely effective in the opening scene, using dark shadows covering the bodies to create a mysterious silhouette, with a perfect amount of light around them to make them visible.

What struck me as the greatest technical achievement was the cinematography. Like the German film 'M', which was made ten years earlier, it has certain uses of the camera which where almost never seen before. If one analyzes the cinematography in the opening scene, you will realize that this camerawork was not common for the time, but it is so inventive and original that it is undeniable that it is ingenious, for example, the use of deep focus and, in the beginning, a fish-eye view though broken glass.

Orson Welles plays Charles Foster Kane in an amazing way. In general, all the performances given are great, because of other talented actors such as Joseph Cotten, who was to later play in other movies like 'Shadow of a Doubt', 'The Third Man', which also has Orson Welles in it, and 'Hush...Hush, Sweet Charlotte'. Even though Joseph Cotten is excellent in this, Orson Welles truly was at his best, even though he was only 25 when he made this film! If you are a film buff, than you must see this, because of its technical accomplishments. For an 80 year-old film, it has not aged a day. Why is this movie an essential in film school? A few reasons are its lighting, cinematography, and character development. This is a must-see for any fan of drama and mystery movies, for any film buff, and any fan of movies. God bless all who read this and bye!

Kids who watch this movie will never know how revolutionary it was.  Every one if its dozens of innovations, from flashback structure to the use of sets with ceilings for additional authenticity, has become standard.  No problem-- there is time enough for them to study these aspects of Citizen Kane's brilliance if they decide to learn more about film history and criticism.  For their first viewing of this brilliant work just let them focus on the story, the dialogue, and the characters, which remain as compelling and contemporary as they were 70 years ago.

Like Willie Stark, Kane begins as a populist and dies corrupt and alone, and we can't help but hope for some explanation of how that happened, as Thompson does.  Both Kane and Stark were based on real-life figures.  Kane was based largely but not completely on William Randolph Hearst, the almost impossibly wealthy heir to the largest gold and silver mine owner in America, who became a powerful publishing magnate.  Kane might also have been based on Welles. himself, only 25 years old when he co-wrote, directed, and starred in this, his first film.  He spent the rest of his life coming up with one excuse or another for why he never came close to that level of achievement again.
The perfect foundation on so many levels of how movies would be made forevermore.

It's earned its place in film history with its masterful use of lighting, framing, effects and revolutionary story structure but it has turned into something more of a symbol of a masterpiece rather than being the greatest film ever made. It's still miles better than the first Suicide Squad movie though.

The film that revolutionized filmmaking, a name that has become synonymous with magnum opus — a true masterpiece — Citizen Kane is the film student's film for a reason. Yes, I had viewed many YouTube videos about Citizen Kane before ever watching the film, but that didn't take away from the enjoyment; I had actually completely forgotten what "Rosebud" meant anyway. Charles Foster Kane (Orson Welles) is on his deathbed in the palatial Xanadu when he murmurs "Rosebud" before expiring. Discovering what this American Titan's last word actually meant propels the film, if only superficially. Welles — who is also the (25 year old!) director — lays it all out in a news-breaking montage of Kane's life, the peaks and valleys, before seeing him as a child playing in the snow. We pretty much know everything that happens 15 minutes-in, now we get to fill in the gaps. Kane is ahead of his time as the newspaper mogul (think Ted Turner, Rupert Murdoch today) who, on day one of taking over The Inquirer, states: "News is 24 hours". Thus, changing the way the city — and eventually, the nation — learned about the world, especially considering he filled those pages with the filth we gobble up like a smorgasbord today. Considered a communist to some, a fascist to others (how topical), Kane engages in many of the activities you'd expect a super-wealthy businessman to engage in — expands his empire, ends friendships, ends marriages, begins new marriages, and builds a palace down in Florida with the biggest fuck-off fireplace I've ever seen. Considered a composite character, your opinion on Kane is probably justified and misguided.. That's to say, he's neither hero nor villain. Although Welles didn't necessarily invent many of the shots in his film, he absolutely changed the director's efficacy in storytelling, with too many to count here. A few include: the shot of Kane's parents (Agnes Morehead & Harry Shannon) with the banker (George Coulouris) who becomes his legal guardian as young Kane (Buddy Swan) is playing in the snow, Kane giving a political speech — the most recognizable scene of the film — with a gigantic poster of himself in the background, and the final shot of all the crates housing his treasures. "One word can't explain a man's life." Our powerful departing words. Oh, and what is "Rosebud"? Eh, watch the film to find out. If anything, to pay homage to that gif you probably (sarcastically) use all the time.

As a movie that is often referred to being the "greatest of all time," I would say watching it is a disappointment. I found no enjoyment watching the movie whatsoever. While the cinematography is fantastic with its deep shots and angles that tell a story all on their own. It is the character of the titular character that sours the movie for me. I found myself rooting for almost everyone who opposed him because I found him despicable. Kane was a power hungry man who's misogyny could be chalked up to the times but his constant disregard for the women he is supposed to spend the rest of his life with is disappointing. It was said very well in the film that he wanted someone to love him, the character himself seemed incapable of love, probably due to his childhood trauma. Normally when someone experiences childhood trauma in movies I find myself at least somewhat sympathetic towards their emotional struggles later in life, not so with Kane. Kane was a character I grew to hate alongside his wives. The fact that the whole movie is about trying to figure out his dying words as if "Rosebud" was a secret code word that would help one to rule the world or perhaps even the stock market felt like a joke. There are some debates in the real world whether "Rosebud" was literal for his sled or if it was supposed to represent his lost childhood and innocence, or even a thousand different other things it could possibly mean if it wasn't just literally about his beloved sled he was forced to leave behind but somehow got magically transported to his massive storage room of expensive collectibles and junk. The debate around the word echos the search for the meaning in the film when I think for a man who was superficial as Kane was tend to think of it being literally about just the sled. He as an old and most likely senile man, which with great age comes lack of sense or great capacity of mental faculties. The last words of a fragile old man can hardly be taken as seriously in the movie or the world outside it. Most elderly when they pass if they say some nonsense words it just gets chalked up to their brains being addled with barely much further thoughts into their meaning. I felt an overwhelming sense of relief once the film concluded and I no longer had to watch the pointless pursuit of the meaning of "rosebud" or the endeavors of a selfish man with no regards for anyone but himself. The amount of care that went into his last words the man who spoke them wouldn't have given a fraction of to anyone else. I am not a person who enjoys movies about unsavory characters and like to have a main character to root for. When it feels as there isn't a single person to root for in a film, watching it just feels like a chore or I could even go so far as to say insufferable.
CK remains one of the two or three top must-see flix of all time, for great reason!  (Don't let that newly discovered Chicago Daily Tribune review take the rose off the bud).

It can't be overstated just how important citizen kane is in the history of cinema. It's innovative use of camera techniques, non linear story and its focus on the psychology of its main character have been cited as influences on virtually every great film maker since it's release. That to me is what makes it the greatest film of all time. Is it the best or most entertaining? I wouldn't say so, but no film is as important as Welles' masterpiece. Watched today after seeing so many other movies, one might not appreciate just how innovative it is as they will have seen its groundbreaking techniques multiple times in other films but it should be kept in mind that so many of those techniques were used here first.

Film combines the brash and showy end of visual storytelling with the depth and episodic quality of good drama or literature, story follows the tale of a freak inheritance bestowing wealth and livelihood upon a young American plutocrat. (Wealthy for owning press, property, resources) . . the film's grasp of character arc, passing time and, really, quite economic storytelling works as both a personal drama and prophetic look at what postwar capitalism, and the fate of the United States awaited as inevitable greed and failure takes hold. 

Also something of a romance, and features commentary on the nature of showbusiness. A classic film that's NOT boring, but also, as mentioned, is from the 1940s - a moment where cinema "grew up" to have the breadth and gravitas of a greater, more satisfying artform.
There's no argument Citizen Kane is the greatest film ever made. If you love filmmaking, cinema or anything that involves movies you need to watch this masterpiece by Orson Wells.

Rosebud. The classic quasi-biography about the rise and fall of Charles Foster Kane.

The camera work was masterful. The use of shadow to build character and smooth transitions between scenes were the most noticeable and easily appreciated. 

When I watched this movie, I was not aware of the real impact that it had to future movies. However, I definitely saw that the plot was repeated in many movies that I have watched. Because of that, even though I wasn't too surprised by the plot, I still appreciated the movie. 

Overall, an fascinating character study. 8/10 (would be much higher if I consider the impact on modern cinema)

A really dark satisfying epic with social commentary that is still relevant today. I was really digging the anti-capitalist vibes throughout the whole movie, although a bit more character development and agency for the few female characters would have been nice. Orson Welles does a fantastic job of portraying Charles Kane throughout his entire life, from an optimistic young man to the exact power-hungry, abusive old man he had vowed against. The film's overarching "rosebud" mystery is actually quite satisfying, and the fact that only the audience (and none of the characters) learn the truth makes it all the more so. The film gets a little bogged down with exposition and the pacing can be off at times, but overall I was impressed by this 80-year-old film's ability to still have a voice in modern times.

AFI 100 Greatest Films - #1: I have finally reached the end of my journey through the AFI 100 (really 99 because I wasn't sitting through Birth of Nation again, having once already for a history course) and only started this list when I went to watch Citizen Kane a couple of years ago and realized there were so many other classics I had never seen. I didn't follow a strict order and tried to catch films in theaters (pre covid) any chance I found, but my only rule was that I couldn't watch #1 until I had completed the entire list ahead of it.

The "best ever" is always going to be hard to live up to in a medium as subjective as film so I was pleasantly impressed that this, while not my #1, was a worthy holder of the crown. The structure of the plot alone had to be quite ahead of it's time and worked so well for the type of investigative look into the entirety of a life, that this film takes us on. I loved the cavernous sets of the Kane mansion which displayed the eye piercing beauty of opulence and wealth, trophies of his conquest over every one of his fellow men, but also fully exhibited and gave the audience a nudge to feel, the immense sense of loneliness a singular pursuit, allowing you to love no one but yourself, can bring about in a person. Welles' acting was superb and the writing was pleasingly sharp as well, which along with the important universal themes being explored through a unique presentation, make it easy to understand why this film is so well respected. 8.5/10

Orson Welles' "Citizen Kane" is an ambitious, poignant and sweeping drama that remains one of the greatest movies ever made. With his directorial debut, Welles crafted a masterful biopic about a newspaper magnate that has stood the test of time as a classic. Welles utilized groundbreaking cinematic techniques that were considered ahead of their time. Using captivating cinematography, Welles draws viewers into the world of a selfish business tycoon. From intimate close-ups to evocative establishing shots, the cinematography keeps viewers immersed in the film's setting. The sets, costumes and musical score are all carefully chosen, combining to create an immersive cinematic experience. Welles' screenplay is also sensational, and expertly uses non-linear storytelling to keep viewers absorbed in the mystery surrounding Kane's death. It is hard to not admire the iconic performances from the cast. Orson Welles delivers one of the best performances of his career Charles Foster Kane. With mesmerizing expressions, he conveys the ambition, torment and selfish persona of the titular business tycoon. The supporting cast, which includes the scene-stealing Joseph Cotten, is also excellent and worthy of recognition. When discussing "Citizen Kane", it is hard to not mention the musical score. Bernard Hermann's classical score is highly effective. It builds palpable tension and suspense. With the exception of its outdated ten-minute expository opening sequence, "Citizen Kane" remains a timeless classic nearly 80 years after its release. A must-see for movie-lovers, it set the stage for influential cinematic techniques that continue to be used in the film industry today. Put simply, it is one of those certified classics that no movie-buff should miss.
Not a perfect movie by any means, but still a must-see for any person wanting to get into film history. This contributed so much to the world of movies that we have today.

I have to preface this review with the fact that I have a major personality flaw in that I am not a big fan of the golden age of cinema or black and white movies in general (The Lighthouse being a big exception).

But I am a big fan of David Fincher so before I watched Mank I thought I should watch Citizen Kane, called by many the best movie of all time.

What struck me from the beginning scenes were the attention to detail and technical prowess on display. No opening credits, the slowly panning shots, the use of closeups, reflections and shadows, the newsreel exposition, the rat-a-tat dialogue, and ultimately the nonlinear storytelling.

I don't know if this was innovative at the time but it was captivating and struck me as unique.

It lost steam at the end when it rushed through his two wives and final years, but man, the final reveal about who/what "Rosebud" was absolutely fantastic!

Of its time, it delivered something never seen before - an honest, puzzled production, with a shifting narrative, unaffected by the Hollywood excitement. Its writing style was also, perhaps, more brazen than most, as well as being more 'real' - wealth and influence crushing a man; its leader, the dark knight of the soul. The success of its lucky writer (Mank was flailing before Welles approached him), is thanks to its auteur - Welles, with both coming together, striking exactly the right tone with a movie that forces the audience to think of both writer and director once they've seen it, as it deliberately leaves questions hanging in the air that can only be explained by those creative minds 'behind the curtain'. It's introduction of new talent, as well as it's 'fresh' approach to telling a relatable tale (loosely based on magnates of the time) saw it well-received upon its release. It's stayed the test of time due to its positive impact on shaping how movies were written, cast and directed thereafter. In terms of the actual story and acting, I'm not sure it struck me as anything particularly 'special' - certainly, it did not meet my expectations. However, I do appreciate its artistry, what it meant, what it still means, and why it is still revered. It is one I'll come back to

Honestly, it's overrated. It pioneered some cinematography techniques that we're all thankful for, but don't be a martyr for film making and sit through this.

It's a true classic —— for cinephiles that is!

"80 years after its release, Citizen Kane continues to be addressed by many as "the greatest movie ever made". It became the most popular film of all-time, one that went through decades of in-depth essays. Everything that needed to be said about it has already been stated, recorded, and written. No movie warrants higher expectations from its viewers, but this massive hype makes it a dangerous film. People fear being judged for not understanding the worldwide acclaim or simply disliking it. Is it a tad boring? Are some actors flat? Is the story not as mesmerizing and memorable as you'd expect? Don't be afraid to say "yes" because all of these opinions are entirely reasonable. None of this contradicts the indisputable influence it had on filmmaking and in the history of cinema. Everything about this movie's production and origin, the precedent-setting technical aspects, and the innovative storytelling all prove that Orson Welles was a perfectionist filmmaker far ahead of its time. Is it the best film ever? That's a never-ending debate I don't wish to be a part of. But it's undeniably one of the most magnificent masterpieces of cinema, one that every movie lover must watch."

Without succumbing to the temptation to fawn over a much loved classic, I have to concede the obvious strengths of this movie as a groundbreaker. The clunkiness of the acting on show from some of the supporting cast members only serves to highlight the brilliance of Orson Welles, whose ease and watchability are way ahead of his time. Likewise, even the cardboard backdrops don't spoil what is a fantastic plot: the story of a man who, had he not been rich might just have been great, and the message that absolute power corrupts even the seemingly incorruptible. The dialogue is witty and pulls the tale along by the scruff of the neck. A really memorable montage shows the descent of Kane's moral rectitude along with his marriage over a succession of increasingly stagnant breakfasts. And when we finally learn the meaning of "Rosebud", Kane's enigmatic dying word, it is wonderfully poignant, revealing the protagonist's lasting fondness for the memories of his youth and the potential, long since wasted, that youthfulness once represented. All that being said, Citizen Kane is undoubtedly of-its-time, and as such requires investment from its audience, who must be willing to suspend their expectation of 21s century slick. It drags in parts, and some of the lesser cast members are more wooden than the backdrop on which the jaw-dropping mountain retreat of Xanadu is painted. But if, in the pursuit of seeing how the pioneers paved the way for the likes of actor/directors like Eastwood and Howard you are willing to overlook such things, you will certainly enjoy - and genuinely enjoy - this film.

===

"Rosebud."

This one word is the catalyst for the events that follow it, as reporters scramble to find out its meaning, only to find out in the end that it means nothing. Citizen Kane is a film built on such paradoxes; just like the titular character, Charles Foster Kane. The narrative is scrambled, told primarily through flashbacks, and tells us everything that will happen in the first 15 minutes; or so it seems. The film is an enigma. Just like Charles, the film keeps us just outside, providing hints that might help us understand it a little more, but in the end, we end up even more perplexed. 

The cinematography was light years ahead of its time; in the newest 4K remasters, it's impossible to tell that the film is 80 years old. Gregg Toland, the director of photography, was already well-known by this point in his career, but it was his contributions to Citizen Kane that elevated him to legend status. Toland and Welles took everything they knew about the medium, and everything they didn't, and threw it at the screen with full confidence. The result was a style that redefined cinema; a strange mixture that called upon German expressionist lighting, Soviet-style montage, experimental sound design Welles picked up working in radio, and silent-era shot compositions, all with a distinct golden-age Hollywood flair.

Toland famously used deep focus to great effect, throwing out conventional framing, and instead relying on complex frame compositions to draw the audience's attention. The pair were relentless in their pursuit to find the perfect look, doing some very bizarre things to arrive at the right angle. They famously ripped holes in the floor to get the low angle they desired, and then had to create special microphones and ceilings made of canvas to be able to capture audio; all for a shot that lasted less than 60 seconds. They sliced tables in half, put them back together again, craned the camera up past the ceiling into the rafters, employed bizarre camera movements, expressive uses of the z-axis, and moody, exaggerated lighting, all of which paid off; the cinematography is still studied in film schools today.

It's a miracle that the film was even released; William Randolph Heart, whom the film was loosely based on, desperately attempted to stop the release of the film. The writer, Herman Mankiewicz, was a cynical drunkard that had been cast out of Hollywood. The cinematographer, Gregg Toland, was a crazy innovator obsessed with film experimentation. The director, Orson Welles, despite having prior experience in theater, had never used a camera in his life.

However, the end result was nothing short of a masterpiece; a movie every bit as fragmented and broken as its titular character.

Charles Kane is a very obviously conflicted man, the non-linear sequencing of the film only serves to amplify that fact. The use of flashbacks is masterful, and it would take days to properly put the scenes in order. As the reporters interview Kane's alcoholic mistress, his ailing old friend, his rich associate, and other witnesses, memories are twisted and distorted as the story loops through time. We learn all about his childhood, his lovers, his friends, his enemies, his rise to power, and his fall from it. 

Throughout his life, Kane wants everything, anything, to fill the void left in his heart as a child, when he was torn away from his parents and his precious sled, named ‘Rosebud.' He tries idealism, politics, romance, before eventually spending his fortune filling a castle with worthless statues, dying an empty man. ‘Rosebud' is more than just a sled; it represented Charles' poor attempts to regain his childhood innocence and his pursuit for love, things many men spend their entire lives trying to attain. 

"All he really wanted out of life was love.
That's the tragedy of Charles Foster Kane.
You see, he just didn't have any to give."

However, Citizen Kane knows that ‘Rosebud' isn't simply an object. It tells us what it is, but not what it means. The film is a very strange meditation on death, one that is simultaneously terrifying and strangely tranquilizing at the same time. Memories are the main vehicle of the movie, and that is how we see Kane, and that is how others will see us after we pass. As we watch the different perspectives, Kane almost seems like a completely different man in every vignette: there is the Kane who was torn from his precious sled as a child, the Kane that ran for president, the Kane who built on opera for his lover, the Kane who bought a castle and filled it with worthless sculptures, the Kane that mentally tortured his wife, the Kane who died alone.

"I don't think any word can explain a man's life. 
No, I guess Rosebud is just a piece in a jigsaw puzzle. 
A missing piece."

Предисловие.
«...у них такое изобилие,
Что тот, кто не осёл, у них слывёт неверным» - Авиценна.

Вступление.
За готическим навесом и томлением нуара, показана как в сказочном сне, атмосфера всего величия, что может быть в понятии любого меркантильного человека.
Дорогое человеку воспоминание, а может и единственное из-за которого имеет ценность в жизни то светлое, чистое, святое и непорочное заключено в его детстве. Где без сантиментов, нравоучительства и излишнего пафоса показаны очень коротко его ранние годы, заключённое именно на столь дорогом ему сердцу предмету. Вещь, олицетворяющую собой, то счастье, которое было так лучезарно в его детстве, возвращая его лучшие воспоминания. Плоть до самой смерти, последнее, что он вспоминает – это ту вещь, символ, выражающий суть данного повествования. Также как зацикливание, заострение на последних словах человека перед смертью. Время от времени показывается воспоминание, как расследование, связанное с юностью мальчика. И то, что стало для него единственным утешением, другом и намного большим, чем простое общение. Эта связь с таким же непорочным и дорогим, может приобретать различные формы, но суть и ценность этого неизмерима. Последний эпизод фильма, всё полностью раскрывает и подготовленного зрителя от понимания пробивает током воздействия мысли.
Шарик с домиком, как у него в детстве и вечной зимой, зимой в душе, зимой в сердце. И лишь та ностальгия его раннего детства может уже согреть его сущность.

Повествование мысли.
Достаток человека, уже зашкаливает от всевозможных ценностей мира. Удовольствия, дворцы и замки, построен искусственный город в самом большом размахе и роскоши. Это всё для мистера Кейна, такого важного и почётного гражданина. Были собраны и привезены все лучшие статуи и произведения искусства. Золото и серебро. Богатства столько, что можно обставить десять всемирных музеев. Животные и птицы, каждой твари по паре, делают его зоопарк самым роскошным, а по аллеям и паркам ходят павлины, вьёт гнёзда фазаны, и поют свои трели соловьи.
Показывая это в своём изложении, настраиваю читателя сначала на картинку, потом на мысль. Как в Библии о царе Соломоне, мудрый Экклезиаст говорит, что это той радости и счастья не принесёт. Всё тленно, из праха и в землю уйдёт. Есть ценности непреходящие, не связанные с материальным миром и руками человека. Сокровища, которые не горят, так как находятся в сердце самом. Оставляющие след в душе намного больший, чем различные драгоценные камни и статуи. Идут по фильму завуалированные и многочисленные сноски на Святое писание. Уже откровенно упоминая Ноев ковчег и мавзолей с заготовленными мраморными глыбами для собственной гробницы в лучших традициях царей и фараонов.

Размышление о фильме.
С цинизмом и едкой шуткой показана дальнейшая середина фильма. Под лозунгом –«Убейте меня, пока я счастлив». Самодовольная ирония идёт в ногу с трудными перипетиями жизни, оставляя след с налётом лёгкости.
Родившейся и росший в нищете гражданин, пробивает себе дорогу на самый «верх». Во владениях Кейна, по сути, оказался весь окружающий его мир, ставя его одним из самых богатых людей в мире. Чутьё и присущая хватка является той необходимой частью жизни, которая добивается успеха. Кардинальные изменения на примере редакции газеты, показывают свежий взгляд и новый подход действий, выведение из затянувшегося «болота». Изменения устава и правил влечёт за собой то нужное стремление и перспективы, которые так необходимы для дальнейшего продвижения. А преданность политической мишуре выявляет ту продажность, чьи мотивы идут в разрез любой идеи. Со своим смыслом улавливается кузница кадров и её предназначение, в становлении потом президентами и верховными вождями в других странах. Но, при нужном управлении, режиме контроля, «дёргая за ниточки».
Многогранность повествования показывает политическую игру. Не давая обещаний, их ненужно будет сдерживать. Человек верит только в себя и в свои силы. И переступая чрез преграды, а порой их и вовсе не замечая, идёт гражданин Кейн по карьерной лестнице, показательно воплощая американскую мечту.

Принципы, которые показаны в фильме с одной стороны есть кабала, с другой утверждённая поступь, закон, союз и договорённость, которая и утверждает характер человека.
Различные "наклёпы" и наговоры показаны в высмеивании общества. Манипуляция на различных постах. Мораль и устои всегда правили и остаются править этим миром. Давая любому гражданину, как взлёты, так и падения. Чтобы выше быть склок и недомолвок, гражданин берёт эту критику на себя, как бы подыгрывая и доделывая этот пасквиль, как хотел бы видеть это другой гражданин. Выставляя его стремление в очернении и грязи на суд читателям основной газеты.
Любовь и ненависть народа, исполнение и прихоти, управление властью читается сквозь кадр. Желание любви всесторонне и многолико в стремлении всё большего насыщения общества и гражданина. Политическая идеология в действии и управление словом может вершить судьбы мира. Есть люди коллекционирующие что либо. А есть во множественном числе «гражданин Кейн» коллекционирующий этих людей. «Покупка» одного человека другим является показателем и мерилом гражданина, всё больше находящимся в данном обществе.

В фильме показана любовь не как высшее чувство, спасительная миссия или жертвенная проза бытия …, любовь показана эгоистичная, ненасытная, разрушающая своей силой и навязчивостью в противовес всем библейским законам. Преследуя свои корыстные планы и желания, гражданин Кейн оперирует даже ей. Говоря сквозь фильм, что единственно правильная любовь для каждого гражданина – это любовь его собственная.
Для публичного человека нет ничего хуже, когда публика, народ не понимает его. Чем больше человек общается в обществе и шумной суете многих, тем больше он испытывает одиночество. Ведь нелюдимый, одинокий человек счастлив этим по своей природе, он не испытывает ту потребность в тишине и молчании, которая так нужна всем остальным людям. Одинокий человек живёт своим одиночеством, а известный на обществе гражданин Кейн, всё чаще испытывает эту нужду. Отправляясь на поиски своей юности, ища там умиротворенности и ушедшего счастья.

Профессиональная часть.
Фильм состоит из довольно быстрых тематических эпизодов, как калейдоскоп перетекающих в логическое продолжение. Выставляя цепочку мышления как в интенсивном расследовании, состоящую из фактов и нарезки флэшбэков в показательном виде. Мастерские съёмки и видеоряд, через оптическую призму. Невзирая на великолепную игру актёров, новшества в монтаже кадра, этот фильм за смысл и высказанную человеческую сущность, долгие десятилетия являлся лучшим во всех списках киноакадемий. Значение данного фильма во всём мире очень высоко. Разбирать анализами критики великий фильм, который, до этих пор занимал первые места – смешно, нелепо и рука не подымется. Скажу лишь, что фильм – полностью Орсона Уэллса, в котором он выступил как главный герой, а также сценарист, режиссёр и продюсер. Рассказывает о жизни медиамагната, который и был основателем всей жёлтой прессы. При жизни полной власти, этот магнат, начал настоящую «войну» против режиссёра. И столь вымученный фильм появился намного позже, чем ожидалось. Выявляя свободу и ценность происходящего.

Психология фильма.
Показана грань насыщения и обладания, с годами уходящая чувственность отношений, с которой идут сначала рука об руку. Далее, преобладание эмоций, потом возвышенные чувства, переживания, понимание, в конце - молчание и самодостаточность. В итоге, выливающеюся пустоту совместного проживания. Он и она живут, почти не замечая друг друга. Замкнутость и пустота являет то нечто, которое витает уже в других мирах.
Любой человек хорошее очень быстро забывает, а что-то его не устраивавшее, помнит очень долго. Люди помнят такое, о чём все остальные даже не подозревают. Показана также душевная составляющая красоты, увиденная на короткое время и больше не принадлежащая тебе, но не отпускающая и преследующая тебя всю жизнь.
Богатство ли влияет на величие человека. Если человек не был бы так беден или так богат, он стал бы по-настоящему великим. И в сущности своей человек, как и гражданин Кейн закрыт от окружающих. И открыться и сказать свою истину тяжело, другим непонятно, и многим не под силу. Воспоминания того, что ты сам потерял по жизни, ещё одно неувядающее присутствие, той любимой грусти, которое бывает таким важным.

Заключение.
Простая, старая вещь, которую можно было купить за бедные гроши, как воспоминание и ностальгия по тому беззаботному и счастливому времени, даёт то необходимое состояние, которое ценится выше всех благ на свете.
Жизнь человека трудно объяснить словами, как и загадку по фильму «Розового бутона». Также как трудно уместить в коротком метраже 70 лет человеческой жизни.

When watching a film considered to be the greatest ever made you bring a lot of baggage into it as your expectations are set so high it would be easy to be disappointed. Shockingly this film never disappoints as it is stunning, innovative and thought provoking 78 years later and it ennobles filmmaking in it's richness of character study and vaulting ambition. We owe so much to this film and it's influence but it's a testament to it's greatness that it can be loved as well as admired without losing any of it's sharpness or intelligence. This was the best film of 1941 and one of the greatest of all time, I would still call Gone With the Wind (1939) the best but I was overjoyed to see in it what everybody else sees.

Media tycoon Charles Foster Kane, Orson Welles, is hugely powerful and influential in the late 1920s in New York City. He dips his toe into politics in the hope of becoming governor but his relationship with the President's niece, Emily Monroe Norton Kane, Ruth Warrick, begins to deteriorate as he has an affair with young singer Susan Alexander, Dorothy Comingore. When the affair is revealed his political ambitions are derailed but he forces his new wife to perform and prove her greatness to her detractors bringing embarrassment to her and isolating him from his critic friend Jedediah Leland, Joseph Cotten. His self destructive nature eventually consumes him as he occupies his time with buying sculptures and those he cares about leave him but after his death a reporter sets out on a mission to investigate his final word, "Rosebud."

The story is able to bring together so many different elements as it works as a critique of yellow journalism and it's influence on politics and as a sad tragedy about a man with greatness in him being brought down by childhood trauma. At just under two hours it is impressive how much time we feel we spend on each plot point, it never feels as though we are rushing through this man's life as each scene seems deliberate in it's use and all of them flow naturally into one another. I felt depressed at the end of the film because despite finding many flaws in Kane's character I was concerned about him and felt saddened at the sight of everyone around him, initially in his thrall, moving away from him slowly and coming to resent him in some cases. Welles, a mad genius himself, must have known in some ways what it was like to be Kane and he leaves us profoundly effected by the shocking final scene in this film.

The film gave cinema innumerable innovations as it uses then uncommon low angle shots, deep focus, the non-chronological timeline and the omniscient perspective that it uses to great effect. These innovations are a big part of why the film is so respected and influential but yet again it never makes the film feel inaccessible. I know very little about film production and what goes into the technical aspects of a film but I was awed by the sight of Welles standing in front of a giant poster reading ‘Kane' with an image of his face upon it and every spotlight in the world hitting him. Throughout I saw so many images that I had seen before so many times due to their iconography but seeing them all together within a compelling narrative made them even more impactful and I sat back and realized that I was watching some undeniable cinematic greatness even with the skepticism that I so often bring into film watching.

When talking about this film you have to talk about the man behind the magic, lead actor, director, co-writer and producer Orson Welles. His presence on screen is so great that it is at times easy to be overwhelmed by him but really only he could have played this role as he is at once charismatic and impossible to look away from and a fragile mess. We feel for him even as we realize he is superior to most of humanity and we would never reach his level of brilliance or bravado but somehow we care that this boy lost his childhood and never recovered from it.

Though this movie is an amazing 78 years old it still is a work of art. The last scene of the movie when the audience finds out that all he wanted was his childhood is amazing and finishes this movie just right. It says what you knew was wrong but what you couldn't quite put words to. In all ways a beautiful film. I give this one a 8.5/10

Wells manages to cram so much information, occurrences, and epochs into a film so short that his imagination seems to have no limit. Almost every scene is a masterpiece of text, lighting, camera movement, and an excellent soundtrack (credit: filmmaker Greg Toland). At the age of 25, Wells managed to reach such a high level that he could not repeat the achievement until his death. In a sense, Wells' life and career are not so different from Kane's; he too lost his parents at an early age, and he, too, was the victim of the corrupt power struggles of the world of journalism and politics in America. Because of the political and economic attack of the millionaire Hearst on "Citizen Kane," Wells' career (1915-1985) did not take off as it should have. Wells died of a bitter, frustrated and unfulfilled man-just like Charles Foster Kane. He left behind a masterpiece of American cinema for future generations.

Hollywood reviewers and cinephiles can't get enough of this film, due to its cinematic filming and its interplay of white, black, and shades of gray.  This is all ridiculous to the average movie goer, who wants an entertaining movie that makes him feel good.  
Citizen Kane is a failure on all fronts.  Long. tedious, boring...thankfully modern audiences never heard of this film and would turn it off almost immediately if they ever saw it.  A beginning college class in film writing -- which is what the Mercury Theatre ensemble were -- could do a better job at screenwriting.  The plot could have been salvaged, but as it stands it is a long, depressing saga put together in slipshod fashion and foisted on the public, who didn't buy it.  It's convenient to blame William Randolph Hearst for its failure at the box office, but had the movie been any good, nothing could have stopped the general public from its doors.  Eighty years later, the film has only grown more juvenile -- as would be expected by a troupe touting its first film.  The critical response to the movie is not understandable.  There's nothing here that merits praise.  Welles' masterpiece was his next film "The Magnificent Ambersons", although he can't be given credit for the final edit on this one.

Following the death of a publishing tycoon, news reporters scramble to discover the meaning of his final utterance. 



The Orson Welles film is generally considered the greatest American film of the sound period, and it may be more fun than any other great movie.


Citizen Kane...has the best of everything: a great director and star, innovative cinematography, dreamlike - even nightmarish - art direction, a sonorous musical score, a skillful screenplay in which comic passages intensify the movie's tragic qualities by means of their grotesque juxtaposition (how lifelike!), a psychological / narrative form that predates our contemporary "psycho-histories" by at least 40 years, and best of all, a memorial word that, when spoken, recalls the film out of thin air.

Often considered the greatest American film Citizen Kane's reputation precedes it- but there is a reason for it. Directed by wunderkind Orson Welles(who was barely into his mid 20s) Citizen Kane is a towering achievement of themes which resonate with anyone of us, and the cinematography and pacing are so good most American filmmakers swear by it. Based on the life of a real life newspaper moghul Kane tells the story through flashback of its titular character Charles Foster Kane(Welles). It is a given that for such a work of art the reputation is indeed going to take precedence. But if seen with an open mind one will realize that Citizen Kane is a work not only ahead of its time but also a precursor of many a character studies done in the Hollywood system. Citizen Kane will stand the test of time, as it has for so many decades now.

What more is there to say about the sheer genius of Orson Welles's Citizen Kane? I'm not sure I can add anything novel to the film's glowing critical esteem, but having finally seen it again, I can at least re-affirm my ardent and unwavering admiration for it.

The mesmeric opening sequence alone blows you away, not just for its cinematographic virtuosity (more of that in a moment), but with its sheer gusto and masterful scale of storytelling. Any film that opens on a series of dissolves has my attention (I based the opening few pages of my Eivissa on this technique, so it's nice to know I've received inadvertent affirmation of that sensibility from the great Orson Welles!) The sentimental snow-glass being dropped portentously, the strange perspectives refracted through the snow-glass, then the immortal dying utterance of "Rosebud" - these all brilliantly set up the film's thesis probing the genesis of Charles Foster Kane. Then this opening, extrovert flourish is immediately counteracted by an antithetical, matter-of-fact news report introducing the figure of Kane in a more 'conventional' way.

It's probably boring to non-cinephiles the amount of swooning commentators do over Welles' command of the medium, but it really is immense, with every second of every frame revealing some kernel of information or emotion through an element of framing, perspective, sound design or storytelling. Most scenes in the film are immemorial, but the melancholic tracking shot to Susan's washed-up Atlantic City show by use of a magical faded cut crystallises the bittersweet end-destination of Kane's failed experiment (his second wife), and the imposing, echoing sound design in Xanadu is amazing - emphasising the de facto mausoleum Kane has built for himself.
A film that viewers only recognise as great once they begin to settle into adulthood.

Is Citizen Kane truly the greatest of all films? That depends on who you ask but the film is indeed a force to be reckoned with. The story is about a lonely newspaper magnate as he loses touch with society and descends into madness and frustration. The cinematography was so influential that many DOPs even today consider Kane to be the film that influenced their style. The emphasis on deep focus, long takes and shadows is revolutionary. Of course at the center of Citizen Kane is Orson Welles who not only is the main lead but also the soul producer and co-writer, and of course the director- this film defines the wunderkind talent and genius of Kane. Such was the impact of this film Orson Welles probably never came out of its shadow. Citizen Kane is a masterpiece and there is no reason to not be enthralled by it.

In this film we see the arc of a wealthy man's life from childhood memories to his aspirations after college, from wielding power in the middle of life to an end that, amidst vast wealth and opulence, simply looks back on childhood, and then goes up in smoke.   Charles Foster Kane (Orson Welles) may have been based on William Randolph Hearst and the film a critique of the 'rich and powerful', but there are elements it that are also universal.  It takes a piercing look into how people change over time, how power corrupts, and how all life is transient.  

Kane may have all of the benefits that money brings, but he's also a little broken inside, with perhaps a narcissistic or attachment disorder stemming from having been given up for adoption by his own biological parents when he was a boy (and that, in turn, hinted as being due to his father's abuse).  He therefore has no real friends, or true love.  He positions himself as a 'man of the people', but he's aloof and above them from all, using them to amplify his own power.  He may collect all of the statues he can find in Europe for his castle in America, but ultimately dies like anyone else, without any real meaning, and his possessions disbursed.  

It's fascinating to watch Kane evolve over the film.  His days as a young man are full of hubris and the desire to run a newspaper, mainly to push social messages.  While he also has a knack for increasing circulation via sensationalism, he's also pure enough to pen a 'Declaration of Principles' that promises to publish truth, free of special interests.  In a fantastic exchange, his friend Jedediah (Joseph Cotten) points out that his first two sentences have started with the word "I", and as we'll see, the 'special interest group' that Kane sells out to is Kane himself.  He gradually morphs to begin abusing the power he has as a publisher, swaying opinions on war, and flat out saying that the people will think what he tells them to think.

Kane's relationships also evolve in interesting ways.  Early on he seems so close with Jedediah, jovial and dancing at office parties, but he fires him without thinking twice about it when Jedediah dares to publish the truth in a review of his second wife's awful performance at the opera.  In a parallel way, we see this second wife (Dorothy Comingore) go from a humble, nice, and honest woman he meets on the street one night to a spoiled and vindictive wife, then bitter alcoholic.  She speaks about Kane over a drink in a two-bit club, and Jedediah speaks about him from an assisted living facility.  The film has a rather dark view of the endgame that awaits us all.

The transience of life is further emphasized by little moments in the supporting cast, such as Bernstein (Everett Sloane) saying of his own life these fantastic lines: "A fellow will remember a lot of things you wouldn't think he'd remember. You take me. One day, back in 1896, I was crossing over to Jersey on the ferry, and as we pulled out, there was another ferry pulling in, and on it there was a girl waiting to get off. A white dress she had on. She was carrying a white parasol. I only saw her for one second. She didn't see me at all, but I'll bet a month hasn't gone by since that I haven't thought of that girl."

Orson Welles is excellent as both actor and director, and the way the story is told, via flashbacks from multiple perspectives and short jumps in time, is compelling.  He also utilizes a number of innovative and interesting visual techniques that feel modern.  If you're looking for a film with an uplifting message, one with action, or one that will leave you feeling warm, this is not your film.  On the other hand, there is such honesty here about power and about life, the filmmaking is fantastic, and it has an ending that is absolutely devastating, in those plumes of smoke going up into the night sky.
A patient and deftly conducted character study featuring a superb performance by virtuoso Orson Welles and exquisite cinematography and blocking.

Is Citizen Kane "The Greatest Film Ever Made"?

Is Citizen Kane "The Greatest Film Ever Made" as is often cited by film critics and fans alike since its release?

I think that is subjective and entirely up to the viewer, that is, you. Someone could trace Citizen Kane's greatness in its legacy and massive influence on every single film it influenced afterwards. I believe that Citizen Kane is the greatest film ever directed. For it is Orson Welles' fine attention to detail, meticulous storytelling, and his utmost care in the crafting of his art that makes Citizen Kane so notable.

He chose very specific sequences, shots, and scenes to hopefully get the audience to understand that man that was Charles Foster Kane. The film starts with a news reel that tells Kane's entire life. We learn the "whens" and "whats" of his life.

Then we follow a journalist hoping to uncover the significance and meaning to Kane's last word: "Rosebud." In this journey, he interviews Kane's "whos": his adopted father, his banker, his best friend, his second wife, and finally his butler. Herein, we find out the "hows" of Kane's life. The intimate details of his mortal coil as Kane's closest citizens experienced them.

Lastly, upon the great reveal of the biggest twist ending in film history, you understand the "why" in Kane's life. Why did Charles Foster Kane do what he did. Why buy things instead of investing, why love who he loved, and in the way he loved. It all makes sense and Welles plotted it all out for you.

For Orson Welles, Kane is just a man that he may explain as a film character. It's all there for you to find out and enjoy as you will for yourself.

Films are unique in the world of art as they are a visual medium for an auteur director to reveal something to the audience. We see what we want to see as well as what the director intends for us to see in their work.

Orson Welles' debut film Citizen Kane is a clear example of a masterful director focusing the audience's view on particular shots, subjects, themes, characters, developments, reveals all through cinematography, editing, and the unique angling of the lens. Welles accomplishes so very much in this movie.

The acting is excellent throughout from all actors and actresses. You believe everyone. The old age makeup and the makeup to make them appear weary and worn is so authentic. The sets are grand, Bernard Herrmann's score is intense and magnificent like the man that is Charles Foster Kane.

However, these are all merely clockwork to the final machination of Citizen Kane as a film. All of these aspects are supervised lovingly and hand crafted by Orson Welles. I think Welles truly made a masterpiece of film. For all its individual parts are remarkable, but what endures about Citizen Kane is how Welles speaks to humanity's greatest theme and motivation: love. It is this simple beautiful thing that we function for, with, and towards evermore.
As good as advertised.

Finally, I got to watch Citizen Kane, and there is no confusion about why this is commonly considered one of the greatest films of all-time. I watched many movies that have been described as "Revolutionary"  and "Game-changing". But besides that Citizen Kane really deserve to be called so more than any movie I've watched in my life, it's could be the oldest movie that is as influential as it is timeless. I felt I was watching a movie the has been released couple years ago, except it's shot in black and white. An ecstasy of light and shadow, of clashing textures and graphic forms. A haunting cinematography that makes Citizen Kane one of the best-looking movies to date. an exuberant use of camera placement and movement and inventive lighting. Yes, it's above all a visual achievement. But all these innovative techniques shouldn't be questioned whether they still hold up or not. Because they don't just hold up to this day, but they are as fresh and contemporary as they were in 1941. But all that is from the technical standpoint, so what about the screenplay, the narrative, the story?

As Orson Welles took many risks directing Citizen Kane he also took risks writing it's Oscar-winning script with Herman J. Mankiewicz. And of course by risks I mean the unprecedented use of flashbacks, and the non-linear storytelling. And While I can't say this way of storytelling paid off perfectly, I have to admit that this structure has changes the game forever in film-making. It took me a while to be engaged with the characters, and the story itself. That's because the pacing was confusingly fast at the beginning, and some important aspects and details in the story needed to be more focused on. 

It also dragged, and almost lost me a couple of times. As I mentioned above, the build up for the titular character could've been way better, at least to make me invested in the character from the start.

With that being said, the more the time goes, the more I became engaged with the story, and invested in all the characters, not only Charles Kane. And I couldn't help but hope for some explanation about the fate of Kane. 

After some more minutes, I realized that Citizen Kane is a character study, actually, a very complex and compelling one. The story became more poignant and moving. By the way, if you still haven't watched Citizen Kane because you think it's a pretty serious and bleak film, you better watch it ASAP. Because it's actually funny! Yes, sometimes it's funny in a cynical way, but it is always a light-hearted movie, and easy to watch. But that doesn't mean it's a feel-good movie at all. As I mentioned, it the story becomes more touching and emotional as it proceeds, and it's represented in a flashback structure to reveal some mysteries about a publishing tycoon's rise and fall who dies corrupt and alone. So I think you get the point.

All the performances are impeccable, and Orson Welles' performance is as terrific as his direction. Also, Joseph Cotten is great as always. 
Also, the dialogue is so clever, and there are a fair share of very subtle lines.

Citizen Kane is far from perfect, IMO. Nevertheless, it somehow lives up to its reputation as a landmark achievement in film. But what's striking now is how utterly modern it is in direction.

Reading reviews and public opinions on "Citizen Kane" really made me wonder if I'd watched the same film, as it's - overwhelmingly often - praised as being the best film ever created. To my understanding, Orson Welles and Gregg Toland could barely be seen as innovators in regards to the various cinematographic techniques used; the thing which made "Citizen Kane" stand out among its predecessors, was rather the combination of many existing ones, combined with an achronological narrating style. Even so, it does not fulfill its contemporary premise.

The film, in its whole basically mixing some sensationalised mystery with a description of newspaper magnate William Hearst's ever-deprecating life (portrayed by none other than Orson Welles himself, a performance which certainly is commendable, in all), is able to deliver good dialogue, with some exceptions wherein the conversations feel forced and too theatricised. Editing is also good, but really nothing to write home about, as this too sometimes leaves (much) to be desired. (And that is without mentioning the consequential and terrible attempts at making fourth wall breaks seem fashionable.)
The so-called "pan-focus" (i.e. the focusing on multiple layers of depth in one shot) seems peculiar the first time it's used, but Welles and Toland milk this kind of camerawork so much that it quickly becomes a - surprisingly annoying - gimmick.
Ironically, the story is built around a single word, "Rosebud", whispered by Kane in his last breath seconds before dying, and the journalistic research thereafter trying to figure out the meaning of said word. Seeing as to how this is the premise of the whole movie, it forms a gigantic plot hole from the very start and at the very base of it; after all, given that not a single person is within hearing range to perceive Kane's dying word and subsequently get the word out about it, the plot driving the movie just doesn't make sense.

Ultimately, where I land on this film, is that it really suffers from the status it's been given: frankly, placing a movie on a pedestal arguing it to be "the best movie ever made" diminishes just such a status, and moreover makes it dilapidate into a category of lesser film. Why? Because of the extreme bias forced onto fresh audiences. Mind you, "Citizen Kane" was crafted very creatively, but in its essence, it's become nothing more than an idolisation and idealisation of its medium, causing nothing but letdown.
I can see the glory which was once there, but also that it has faded just because of its presence. Quite sad, really.
